{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3409464,"name":"Wihy","username":"Wihy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wihy/{size}/225659_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-19T09:12:31.220Z","cooked":"

Hi.
I have a generic motor class with the following inputs. All motors use this Inputs class, and so log all of these fields.

image736×451 54.1 KB

However, some motors never use any of these fields, and so it unnecessarily logs a lot of empty fields, which isn’t very efficient…
Is it possible to log only certain fields, but still use one Inputs object for all motors?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-07-19T09:12:31.220Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":114,"readers_count":113,"score":107.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":468859,"topic_slug":"dynamically-modify-advantagekit-logged-values-on-runtime","display_username":"Wihy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61960,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Driver & Software Lead"},"post_url":"/t/dynamically-modify-advantagekit-logged-values-on-runtime/468859/1","custom_user_title":"Driver & Software Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3409477,"name":"Jonah Bonner","username":"jonahb55","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-19T13:11:05.931Z","cooked":"

The AutoLog annotation is provided to make logging more convenient with the most common structure for inputs, but is absolutely not required. You can manually implement LoggableInputs (as described in the docs) if you want to do something more complicated with selectively logging fields.

In general, the fact that different subsystems have different requirements for input data is the reason our recommended structure uses separate input objects (and IO implementations) for each subsystem. But AdvantageKit is also designed to let you deviate from our recommended structure, so feel free to experiment with alternatives!

What do you think will be lost with this kind of structure? Assuming you have automatic simulations from motor settings and such.

Thanks for the reply!

My current attempt

image860×483 84.1 KB

I ended up with this design. Each motor will return a list of booleans, which will decide what inputs to log.
Though I don’t know which is better at this point with all these if statements.
If anyone has an idea for a better way of implementing lmk

levyishai:

What do you think will be lost with this kind of structure? Assuming you have automatic simulations from motor settings and such.

Automatic simulations from motor settings? I wonder who did that

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-07-19T13:22:51.520Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":77,"readers_count":76,"score":50.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":468859,"topic_slug":"dynamically-modify-advantagekit-logged-values-on-runtime","display_username":"Wihy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":44471,"username":"jonahb55","name":"Jonah Bonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61960,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Driver & Software Lead"},"post_url":"/t/dynamically-modify-advantagekit-logged-values-on-runtime/468859/4","custom_user_title":"Driver & Software Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3409565,"name":"Jonah Bonner","username":"jonahb55","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-19T19:28:54.970Z","cooked":"
Wihy:

Though I don’t know which is better at this point with all these if statements.

I think it’s just a matter of personal preference. The alternative would be to define separate inputs classes for each subsystem (or each type of subsystem with unique inputs). It’s more code but may be easier to understand — that’s up to you to determine. On 6328 in 2024, we mostly had separate inputs for each subsystem but used generic versions for very similar subsystems (like all of the various rollers for manipulating notes, which all used similar open loop control).

levyishai:

What do you think will be lost with this kind of structure?

Aside from preference over which method is “cleaner,” it’s important to consider how subsystems might have different requirements. In the example of our roller subsystems, we had shared IO interfaces and IO implementations since all of the roller motors could be configured the same way. That wouldn’t work for (say) an arm subsystem, since we needed more specialized functionality in the IO implementation. If your subsystems have a lot of similarities, it’s perfectly viable to share code between them.

At a higher level, the reason we don’t include generic wrappers like this in AdvantageKit is to make it as open as possible for teams to experiment with. Teams may not agree even on relatively simple questions like “what’s a good default motor controller configuration?”, so we prefer to leave that kind of abstraction out of the library. We provide an example structure so that teams have a reference point to get started with, but there’s no intention that it is prescriptive (notice that the library itself doesn’t have anything which requires “IO layers” at all, we just provide examples of that structure because it’s a useful starting point).

jonahb55:

define separate inputs classes for each subsystem

Something I dislike about this approach is how much boilerplate is needed to write something as simple as running a motor with akit + sim.
Mostly following the conventional approach you mentioned, I ended up with around 6 classes for a very basic kicker subsystem

For this reason and others I decided to create a generic wrapper for all hardware, essentially handling sim and akit inside each device individually.
That way the code will look much of the same as akitless and simless code, but with the added bonus of akit and simulation with very minimal effort (As much as 2 extra lines for sim, and noone needed for akit)

jonahb55:

At a higher level, the reason we don’t include generic wrappers like this in AdvantageKit is to make it as open as possible for teams to experiment with.

I completely understand your standpoint. That seems like a very reasonable approach
